author: ryzu99
body:
My 2 cents, conglomerates may have worked in the past but not in the present. Having multiple industries with little synergy between them can be interpreted as diversified income, but I view it as a lack of focus among the management team. Jack of all trades, master at none. It also introduces a lot of admin costs within the company.

As an example, Verisign. Only selling internet domains and management has laser focus on one industry. This shows up in their high margins

author: greytoc
body:
I started before then and no I did not miss out as you you misinterpreted. The market has always been forward looking - that has not changed.  And I was fortunate that at the time, I was fairly diversified and still accumulating so the draw-down that I experienced was quite recoverable and didn't have lasting impact. But I am sure that wasn't the same for everyone. 

If you were fortunate to have chosen a stock that recovered quickly and continued to climb then that's great. But that was not true for many other high-flyers stocks. Cisco for example has never recovered from it's highs. Akamai has never come close to recovering. Microsoft took about 10-15 years to recover.  Verisign which was the hot cybersecurity stock or the day is now only starting to recover. And the broad market took a good 10-15 years to recover back to the same level. Also - don't forget the many companies that evaporated like [Pets.com](https://Pets.com), webvan, etoys, [agency.com](https://agency.com), Doubleclick.  These are just the ones that I remember because I either swing traded them or they were core holdings in my portfolio at the time. 

Yup - EV and clean energy are part of my portfolio but I will continue to hedge and protect my hard-earned capital.
